SpinDec2
Software Modelling Spinodal Decomposition
Pseudo-Spectral Solver

Pseudo-Spectral Cahn-Hilliard Solver

The basis of using Pseudo-spectral methods is to use fast Fourier transforms to simplify the calculation of derivatives in partial differential equations. In the spectral method, the solution \(c\), is expanded in a suitable set of basis functions, for example plane waves: $$ c(x,y,t) = N \sum_{ij} \alpha_{ij}(t)\exp{i(k_i x + k_j y)} $$

where N is some normalisation constant.

If we take the Cahn-Hilliard equation:

$$ \frac{\partial c}{\partial t} = M\left(\nabla^2 \mu -\kappa \nabla^4 c \right)$$

the derivatives which are generally estimated via finite differences simply become factors of the wavenumbers, \(k_i, k_j\), such that the Cahn Hilliard equation is now be taken to be:

$$ \frac{\partial \tilde{c}}{\partial t} = M\left(-k^2 \tilde{\mu} -\kappa k^4 \tilde{c} \right)$$

where \(k^2 = (k_i^2 + k_j^2)\) and \(\tilde{c}, \tilde{\mu}\), are the fourier transforms of concentartion and bulk chemical potential resoectively.

However, an issue does occur when discretising the above equation. As bulk chemical potential depends on the concentration grid. We can only estimate this at the current time step and not the next such that:

$$ \frac{\tilde{c}^{k+1}_{i,j} - \tilde{c}^{k}_{i,j}}{\Delta t} = M\left(-k^2 \tilde{\mu}^{k}_{i,j} -\kappa k^4 \tilde{c}^{k+1}_{i,j}\right)$$, In which the next iteration can be estimated by rearranging the above eqaution: $$ \tilde{c}^{k+1}_{i,j} = \frac{\tilde{c}^{k}_{i,j} - M\Delta t k^2 \tilde{\mu}^{k}_{i,j}}{1 + M \kappa \Delta t k^4}$$.

After this only one thing is left to do, and that is to perform the inverse fourier transform on \(\tilde{c}\) to get back to the real concentartion grid.

This method above is rudimentary and isn't the most accurate and stable way of discretising the problem. In SpinDec2, we use the work of Zhang et al. to implement a more accurate and stable method of solving the above Cahn-Hilliard using Fourier transforms.

The paper discusses using more reliable time discretisation methods for the time derivative and alternative ways to handle the non-linear chemical potential term. Specifically, the non-linear term is discretised to include a stability term \(A\), which allows for larger time steps to be simulated:

$$ \tilde{\mu}^{k}_{ij} \rightarrow 2 \tilde{\mu}^{k}_{ij} - \tilde{\mu}^{k-1}_{ij} + \Delta t A \left(\tilde{c}^{k+1}_{ij} - 2\tilde{c}^{k}_{ij} + \tilde{c}^{k-1}_{ij}\right) $$.

This stability term can be controlled in SpinDec2 using the stabilization_term variable in input.txt .

Authors: Anas Siddiqui, Ben Gosling, Dyaln Morgan, Geraldine Anis, Matyas Parrag
